The author ignores several key points:

General warrants are unconstitutional. As he writes, the Constitution requires that search warrants must be "...particularly describing the place to be searched...: Key word: Particularly.

That includes the entire Trump Administration, from start to finish. This would cover everything from classified nuclear secrets (relevant to the National Archives records supposedly at issue) to President Donald J. Trump's thoughts on whether to serve ice cream or cherry pie at a lunch with members of Congress (utterly ungermane to the matters at hand).

As it happens, this raid -- we now learn -- including snatching photographs of Trump, a framed copy of Time magazine, and even several items of clothing. Did this include classified ties? Top secret shirts? Nuclear cufflinks?

It seems likelier that the FBI just opened a net, dragged it through Mar-A-Lago, and threw the entire net into a truck. Then they sifted through it for days, picking out whatever they found interesting.

Blah, blah, blah. All this "search warrant" talk is a smoke screen for the real issue - were the documents declassified? A court ruled that documents in the possession of a FPOTUS are "presumptively declassified" (the court's words), because a POTUS has plenary authority to declassify documents, and there is no rule by which he must do so. Just handling the documents as if they are declassified declassifies them, because declassification is within his authority and there can be no presumption the POTUS is committing a crime when his handling of such documents can be legal through his power to declassify. If a POTUS retains documents after he leaves office, the legal presumption is that he declassified them before leaving office.

A POTUS also has plenary authority to designate documents "presidential" (potentially disclosable by the NARA, if the NARA gains control of them) or "personal", which can be permanently hidden from the public. (This too has already been adjudicated, when a court refused to order NARA to do that which NARA was not empowered to do - to seize and disclose certain records held by FPOTUS Bill Clinton.) Trump could consider any and all of the records in his possession "personal" and he would have no obligation to turn them over or to disclose them to anyone. Even NARA can be forced to negotiate the surrender of presidential records, and there is no timeline for the FPOTUS' surrender of such documents. A FPOTUS can delay such negotiations indefinitely.
